addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight, Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie
.

10 Sep
t
1589
From M
r
Thomas Bodley.

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H since I writte
e former
whiche I send yo
r
H. heerew
t
, we have certaine in-
telligence,
at
e Enemie is returned into
Bommels
Weert
, w
t
greater forces then before, having there al-
ready, and in those quarters, not so fewe as 1300
Enseignes: of w
ch
, it is said,
at he sendeth 48
Enseignes towardes
Nieumeghen,
there to passe the
river, others towardes
Frise,
and
e rest to be
imploied in
e siege of
Hoesden,
and in forcing
a passage over
e Wael. The Contrey heere is
muche perplexed uppon this soddain returne of
e Enemie, longing earnestly for
e supplie of her
Ma
ties
forces, w
ch
I trust,
e winde serving, ar-
rived ether yesterday, or to day, at
Flushing.
They doe also sommon all suche souldiers, as lye
scattered abroad in townes, and receave, as they
terme it, Waertgelt, w
ch
is some litle portion
of pay, uppon c
o
dition to be in readines, when
e
state heere shall require their service: of whiche
kinde of souldiers, it is judged,
at they may
raise 8 Enseignes. It is further resolved,
at
e
Generall states
, and
e
Councell of state
,
shall remove from hens
e 13 of this moneth, and
hold their assemblies at
Gorchum:
where they
may be able w
t
more certaintie and speed,
both to understand
e Enemies attemptes, and
give order for resistance. I am purposed to
keepe in c
o
pany w
t
them, as
ei doe also req
e
st
me. But if occasion of service so require, I
will move
M
r
Gilpin
(who is yet at Flushing)
to remaine in this place: albeit I see no ne-
cessitie as yet of
e presence of ether of us heere,
if all
e rest shall depart.
And thus I take
my humble leave. From
e Hage. 10 Sep
t
89
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
